name: Chronic Open Angle Glaucoma Management
citation: NICE Guideline NG81: Chronic Open Angle Glaucoma Management
rules: IF person has chronic open angle glaucoma AND does not want SLT THEN offer a generic prostaglandin analogue (PGA).
IF person with chronic open angle glaucoma is waiting for SLT AND needs interim treatment THEN offer a generic PGA.
IF SLT is not suitable for a person with chronic open angle glaucoma THEN offer a generic PGA.

IF person cannot tolerate a pharmacological treatment THEN consider a medicine from another therapeutic class (beta-blocker, carbonic anhydrase inhibitor, or sympathomimetic) OR preservative-free eye drops IF allergic to preservatives OR has symptomatic ocular surface disease.
IF person's intraocular pressure (IOP) is not sufficiently reduced despite treatment with PGA THEN ask about adherence to treatment and eye drop instillation technique.
IF person has newly diagnosed chronic open angle glaucoma THEN topical medicines from different therapeutic classes may be needed at the same time.
IF person's IOP has not been reduced sufficiently after surgery THEN consider further glaucoma surgery OR cyclodiode laser OR 360° SLT OR pharmacological treatment.
IF person with advanced chronic open angle glaucoma prefers not to have surgery OR surgery is not suitable THEN offer treatment with medicines from different therapeutic classes.
IF person’s adherence and eye drop instillation technique are satisfactory THEN offer further treatment and continue to monitor IOP.
IF effects of initial 360° SLT have reduced THEN consider a second 360° SLT.
